They build little houses of wood on the ice and paint them in bright colours. Then they sit inside to catch the fish that swim under the ice. What's It Like?      "How's it goin'?" a young man asks. I look over at the group he's with. They're laughing, sharing a joke that doesn't seem to include him.      "I'm just lookin' at you for a second," he says.      "Are you the fisherman that lives in that house out back?" he asks.      "Yeah, that's me."      He smiles. We shake hands.      "It's a good job you do," he says.      A Canadian fishermen sits in his house out back on Lake Nipissing during the winter. He builds a little house on the ice, paints the wood in bright colours, and sits inside to catch the fish under the ice. Given this story: Marco stood at the door of Silvia's flat and watched Gabriel leaving. He looked carefully at his clothes and his shoes. Why didn't Silvia open the door? She was in there. Then suddenly it opened. 'Silvia dear' Marco said 'you look wonderful...' He stopped. Silvia didn't look wonderful. Her face was red and she looked unhappy. Silvia looked back at him. “I’ve tried everything Marco. It was a complete waste of time. I gave it my best shot!” Marco felt his cheeks heat. His best shot would have been...? Silvia smiled. “Don’t worry honey. There are more ways to get your girlfriend than to spy on her. I’ll go downstairs and call the police.”  They sat on the sofa and Marco told Silvia about his problems. She listened quietly. Her face was warm with love. Then she said “I think you’re right. There are other ways. I’ve been thinking and the solution seems so obvious.” Marco laughed. That wasn’t the answer he’d been waiting for but he couldn’t help it. “Tell me about it.” she asked.  “One of the problems is that I don’t like the idea of doing anything with my girlfriend that someone else could see. Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer and a teacher and a dentist before he became a writer of children’s books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day he goes into his office and writes. In the evening, he gives the work to his wife to read.        Bill Prince-Smith is the youngest of eleven children and grew up on a dairy farm near Horsham, Pennsylvania. He had a very varied and interesting childhood and developed a passion for all the ‘stuff’ that surrounded his parents, including the farm animals, the house, and the farm machinery. The rural setting gave Bill an unending supply of stories and anecdotes, and he was determined to bring all this ‘stuff’ down to the youngest readers possible.      He graduated from the Pennsylvania State University and worked for a short time as a farmer and dentist, then moved to Los Angeles and taught at the University of Southern California and Loyola University. Here he wrote and illustrated two textbooks, and taught composition and literature at the USC Extension School. He also produced many instructional videos for the university television station.      As an author, Prince-Smith began with “Moo”, a book of short stories which won a Blue Chip Book Award and the Newbery Medal. “Baa!” won the American Library Association Award. .

Kilimanjaro is the second highest mountain on Earth after Everest, so it is a serious challenge. It takes at least three days to climb it, because you need time to acclimatise yourself. It would be hard to get there, but the water would be shallow and they would be able to make it. There was something to be said for the captain's decision: "It's time to keep moving," he said. "We're getting close."
And with those words, the sails were lowered, the rigging tightened and the ship started to turn.

"I am the ship that goes forth to sea," Hayes said. "I am the ship that shall stand against danger. I am the ship of the man who has his head screwed on."

Given this story: THE ICEHOTEL For many years the Arctic was a popular destination in the summer season to see the land of the midnight sun but in winter the few inhabitants had the snow and ice to themselves. By the end of the 1980s it was decided that the dark and cold winter should be seen as an advantage. The Icehotel was built by the Norwegian tourism board in the shape of a giant ice cube, and lies in the middle of the Arctic Ocean.  The purpose of the building is to increase tourism in the Arctic, where summer temperatures average 7 degrees Celsius (44 degrees Fahrenheit). The Icehotel has been used as a TV news station, but also as an ice hotel for conferences and awards ceremonies.  The building is covered in ice, and is designed to retain the winter temperature as close to zero as possible. The building has six rooms, each with their own private bathroom, and the ice-cold water is piped directly to each room. At the back is a restaurant, a coffee shop and a gift shop.  The Icehotel has a large TV screen at the top, which broadcasts news from Norway and around the world. In winter the ice on the TV screen melts, revealing the building as an open-air theatre and dining room. The Icehotel is one of many tourist attractions to be found in Norway’s Arctic regions, many of them aimed at winter tourism. For example there is a “ice hotel” near Tromso, and two hotels built by the Norwegian military, one serving as a base for tourists, the other hosting NATO staff. The “ice hotel” in the town of Longyearbyen has also opened in summer and has a number of visitors every day during the summer.  This article.

Given this story: Climbing to the top of Britain Each year thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland and because of its northerly location the climate can be bitterly cold. Climber Keith Hewitt describes his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February my first big winter climb. Our route was up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. The moment I first saw the Ben Nevis I knew I wanted to climb it. It has a wonderful combination of a stunning scenery, a great view, fantastic terrain, plenty of ice, snow and grit, and a challenging climb. It was a perfect spring day and I knew this was the day I would start my career as a mountaineer. My mind raced as I stood on the summit with a panoramic view over the North York Moors and to the north a long, dark shape was visible. It was a distant shadow of a man sitting on a rock looking at us. This gave me an idea: what if I jumped off the mountain? I took a look around me and found a spot on the rock below the cliff-edge where I could jump. It was a very cold day and I was a bit scared of falling but I jumped and landed safely. I was very excited to have made it all the way from the bottom of the mountain to the summit. It's all a bit of a blur but I'm sure that if I didn't have my friend there to help me then I would have been very upset. That climb was a dream come true and is a highlight of my career. I have always been fascinated by mountains. I have grown up in the north west of England, which is a paradise of mountains. One of the great things about climbing mountains is that it's very social and you can often see and meet people who you share a common.

This is the Albuquerque Balloon festival an annual nine-day event. The first festival was held in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of the local radio station. The Albuquerque Balloon Fiesta was first held in 1972, and was a public-private partnership between the city of Albuquerque, New Mexico, the Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta Association and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.      The festival has since grown into an annual nine-day event. Over the years, it has been held across five different locations, and at present is staged at three sites in New Mexico, three in Taos, New Mexico, and one at the National Balloon Museum in Alamogordo, New Mexico. Each year, thousands of people attend to watch hundreds of hot air balloons rising into the sky, which take flight at various times of the year.      What makes Albuquerque such a popular ballooning destination?      Although the main factor seems to be the beautiful skies of New Mexico, the local government has a more sinister motivation - it is looking to secure the city as a site for a possible NASA Mars base.      The city government's official purpose is to "support the economic interests of the region". This, in combination with the scenic views and the fact that the site is protected from any wind, sand or dust storms, is what encourages ballooning enthusiasts from all over the world to visit. The city is currently a joint bid to become the second base of the National Space.

About two-thirds are heavily involved—either very involved or very involved—in deciding which content they read or watch, and almost half are actively involved in creating content, the study found.
This study is the first to identify these active users as “newsmakers” and measure their activity, said Benjamin Franklin College’s Nicholas Turner, an author on the study and co-founder of the Media Lab at the London School of Economics. 'I think we can be certain she hadn't been burgled.' 'But if Marina Gregg had been injured as you believe,' interrupted Craddock, 'why did she insist on coming back to the flat when she could have used the lift?' Cornish looked surprised. 'She couldn't have made it down the stairs by herself. I was told that the maid was helping her.' Craddock nodded. 'She must have remembered the password. She must also have remembered the secret key. We've only just begun to find out about her, and she's already so clever.' 'You said that she told you about the key,' said Cornish. Given this story: No Title The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six" says Margaret Porter a violinist and music teacher. "It's the time when you are learning about the world." Margaret who lives in London prefers to take pupils at three and four although she has made lots of exceptions for keen five-year-olds. One afternoon this week I spent five hours with a five year old violin pupil from Liverpool who was struggling mightily. After a couple of lessons I'd convinced myself that she wouldn't go anywhere and had no idea whether she'd even make it to ten. We were in the garden. She looked as if she wanted to cry. Her mother was beside herself, too. I was going to have to make a decision. "Sit down and look out the window," I said gently, "it's very pretty out there." She looked at me with pleading eyes and I realized she wasn't in it for the money. "Look," she said, "the houses look so quiet and far away." She wanted to share in the experience. That is the experience of learning a violin, of sitting in a quiet garden looking through its shutters at a different world. She was keen. She'd spent most of the afternoon with her hand over the back of her hand so the tip of the violin would sit comfortably between her shoulder blades. She wasn't even fussy about which type of violin she liked. "I hate the cello," she told me. "The cello's big and ugly. But I like that one." As I listened to her, I decided that for her to make it there had to be some real hope. And so, I told her about the music we would make together. "The one thing I can guarantee you is that the music will get easier.

Given this story: Hi - I'm Justin Rowlatt and I'm the BBC's 'Ethical Man'. So what does living ethically mean? Giving up the car recycling wine bottles not using plastic bags? I spent a year trying to find out. I want to be clear about one thing right from the start - it wasn't my idea to become the BBC's ethical man. For a long time I couldn't tell if I was doing the right thing or not. Why? Because ethical behaviour seems subjective and it can be very difficult to assess the 'right' behaviour. What happens if you try and do the right thing in the wrong way, or with the wrong intentions? The problem is we rarely know if we are doing the right thing to begin with. This is when I started my ethical journey. I spent a month in Nepal working with local organisations trying to raise money and awareness and, in the process, I got to experience the power and transformative strength that a culture of giving has. Given this story: We went to the park. We knew of fifty-two sons in prison. We made a circle of lights one for each son. People stopped to look at the dancing lights and came to ask about our campaign. By the time it was dark our camp had grown to more than fifty women. We had the most extraordinary success. We brought our protest to the city of Los Angeles, the seat of politics. But the politicians took offense. They asked their own public servants to stop us, they hired their own secret service to protect them, and they put up checkpoints all around our camp, stopping every car that drove by. Even though we didn't do anything wrong, it was the worst thing that anyone could do to us. But they could not stop our lights from dancing. In the end, the lights went out in all fifty states. Our lights kept dancing in the dark and we danced together with our fellow Americans who could not see. We knew that our lights were a part of something larger than ourselves and we danced on in unity, singing and playing musical instruments. And as we danced on, all fifty states came to the conclusion: there are fifty-two sons in prison. In a few weeks the lights will return to all fifty states. But for now, our friends in prison have our light. We are all brothers in prison. If you'd like to support us, visit the web site for Families of Prisoners: http://www.familiesofprisoners.org/fodp/home.html.  Take a look at our blog: http://blog.familiesofprisoners.org/ Learn more about prisoners and their families at www.insidecasa.org.  And join us in supporting FODUS.

Given this story: SUNNINGDALE HOTEL The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has provided excellent service for people from all over the world and people of all ages and nationalities have stayed here. During the past 80years over 50000 guests from 174different countries have visited Sunningdale. The hotel is on one of the main roads leading to the town centre. The Sunningdale Hotel dates from the early 1920s. It first took the name 'Sunningdale Hotel', being a reference to nearby Sunningdale Farm which it stands on, then it was renamed 'The Sunningdale', which reflects the owners' love of the countryside surrounding the hotel. The owners spent a great deal of time there, often on horseback, or riding the miles of country lanes.  In the early 1960s a new development was made on the site of the old farm. A new building was constructed to cater for the increased number of guests coming to Sunningdale. This building, along with the original Sunningdale, has retained much of its original character. The hotel offers comfortable and clean accommodation for the whole family.  One of the many great pleasures for families at Sunningdale is to take the long walk around the farm. The countryside is wonderful; there are no streets and the houses are set back from the road, creating a feeling of privacy. The gardens of the hotel are also a great attraction, especially in summer time, especially the pond. It has been possible to take young people on horseback through the gardens. Sunningdale has been used for a number of film shoots. They include, 'Cyrano de Bergerac', 'Doctor Zhivago' and 'Titanic'.  The Sunningdale Hotel is a wonderful place to stay and has been able to carry on its reputation of being a friendly local.

Many people came to the area hoping to get rich. New towns were built and grew quickly. One such town was called Iditarod which means 'far distant place'. In the 1880s gold was discovered in what is now the most northern state of the USA Alaska. Many people came to the area hoping to get rich. New towns were built and grew quickly. One such town was called Iditarod which means 'far distant place'.    The name 'Iditarod' came from a sled dog. It was not known at the time that dogs would be used in sled dog races. The musher's job would be to get the team over the finish line as soon as possible. The dog mushers' dogs would pull the sleds along by pulling the musher's body behind the dogs. The musher wore tights over his own legs which he had to pull tightly around his body in order to stay warm.  From the start of the race to the finish, the team of mushers covered more than 1,000 miles and raced through Alaska's arctic regions. Some were forced to abandon their dogs when they reached the arctic wilderness. For this reason the Iditarod musher is called the 'Iditarod Strong Man'. The Iditarod dog sled race was very popular amongst the locals. It was something that they could enjoy as a sport and a holiday and, because of its great success, it has grown into one of the most popular sports in the world.  The Iditarod is still run to this day, every March. The race will be continued until someone finishes the race..

Given this story: Rock Band Two years agoour 14-year-old s onBen asked us for a set of drums for his birthday. At firstwe were very much against the idea because of the noise. 'It's better than watching television or playing computer games in my free time' Ben argued ’and it'll keep me out of trouble.' In the end we gave in. “We'll only use them in the morning before school,” I said. “After lunch we'll play our video games. And after dinner, well, you can play your rock band if you want.” “Well,” Ben reluctantly agreed, “it's a deal.” I still have a little trouble convincing him about my ideas, but I can feel a shift in the way he sees his future. “I'll go get the drums now,” I said. “But be quick. It won't be safe to wait that long without them.” The next morning I got out of bed and grabbed my clothes. By the time I'd gathered my keys, my sneakers, and the four drums I heard Ben's door shut. I ran to the garage and found the four drums leaning against a refrigerator box that sat in the middle of the garage. I walked toward the living room and saw Ben sitting at the kitchen table. “Hey,” I said, smiling. “I got the drums for you.” “Cool.” “I know you're hungry, so I packed your lunch, too.” We both took a bite of lunch. “And I hope you don't mind,” I said, “but I'm keeping the drums.” I sat down with my laptop in front of me, while he sat at the kitchen table.

Given this story: Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving the sport in which competitors reach extraordinary depths on only one breath of air. In 2003 Tanya Streeter made history when she became the first person to dive 120 metres into the ocean while holding her breath and come back up to the top without help. Free-diver Tanya Streeter holds four world records in a sport where competitors reach extraordinary depths on only one breath of air. In 2003 she became the first person to dive 120 metres into the ocean while holding her breath and coming back up to the top without help.      In the same year she also broke a record previously held by the late British star Richard Hughes, and now holds two records in the same discipline: the longest free dive (120 m) and longest free-diving ascent (170 m).      But she does so on a boat, which means she has only the crew to protect her, as opposed to being underwater alone. “There’s an incredible sense of accomplishment. It’s also an incredible way to die,” she says.      For the last seven years Streeter has been part of the team at Blue Ocean Society, a charitable organisation based in St Kitts, which provides recreational diving and diving education to the underprivileged.      “The project began as a simple idea that there was a way of diverting some of the funds that would otherwise be spent on tourism away from areas that were becoming unsustainable,” she said.      The organisation provides scholarships for students in the Caribbean and Africa, helps to pay for equipment for those that can afford it, and helps to maintain the dive sites where its divers operate..

She also set a record for the longest free-diving ascent, travelling 170 metres underwater with only one breath of air, in a free dive. 
Now, she and her Blue Ocean Society team have developed a new concept for a charity: free-diving for those in need.

The charity also has an education programme that teaches diving skills to local people, but they also use their boats to take tourists on dive trips, so that they can focus on charity instead.

Given this story: MONEY What is money? The pound the dollar or the franc are actually just like a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can exchange money for something else. A five pound note may buy a book a huge bag of sweets or a couple of cinema tickets. Money is a medium to transfer and store value and is an integral part of almost all economic activities. Many people, however, fail to notice that money does not necessarily have to be paper notes. We can, and do, trade in intangible things. Some would say we have entered a new economic age where money is no longer the most important thing but the medium of exchange. You may be asking yourself why, then, am I using so much paper for money when the internet, and social media, are much quicker and easier ways to make a transaction or exchange value? The answer is that paper currency is a good medium for money, or at least paper money in the form of £20 or £50 notes. This is because there are many people who do not own a phone or tablet. Or even more to the point, don't want to use a phone or tablet as it is too distracting and can impede you from paying attention to what's going on. On the other hand, it is a far easier method of money for some people. You can also pay for your things, and get your money, in exactly the same way as before using cash. There are various reasons why people use cash over other forms of money, including: They are uncomfortable giving away personal details over the internet. They are reluctant to give information over the phone. They don't like to make payments online due to payment processors fees. They want the money in a bag.

Given this story: Watering the Desert  It can rain at any time between November and March in Marrakesh Morocco. It doesn’t happen frequently and when it does the city’s water pipes can’t manage the sudden floods which turn the streets into rivers. But as many winters have remained dry in recent times when the rain does come it is welcomed by the local people. When a Moroccan government minister made a visit to the country’s deserts and lakes in mid-December he discovered a desert parched and dry as a bone. “People are scared for the future of their country,” he said. “Climate change is already affecting agriculture.” The minister wasn’t just talking to the media. A Moroccan research team, led by Professor Mohamed Abdelhamid at the University of Fez in northern Morocco, had the same thought. “If we don’t do something about climate change,” he told the media, “in 10 years we will have a desert from Casablanca to Rabat.” In other words, the desert from the Moroccan capital Rabat to the capital Marrakech – the only modern city in a country whose history dates back to the 9th century and has been the home of several kings and a global hub for the spice trade. The team of scientists took their warning to the people. They handed out flyers in cities across Morocco that announced the creation of an organisation called “Climate Change Action Committee”. Morocco’s desert stretches across 2.7m square kilometres (1.05m square miles). It is about 1,000 kilometres long and about 100 kilometres wide and although it never completely rains here, it does produce some snow in winter. Given this story: No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection New Writing 3 although I cannot understand why. Surely 500 pages of original writing of this quality for £6.99 is pretty amazing? Fiction - both parts of novels and complete short stories - makes up most of the book. There are some enjoyable pieces by famous writers such as Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. The main thing that sticks out about New Writing 3, is that, for the most part, it's just OK. There's a fair bit of good writing in there (most notably the short stories of Rose Tremain and Candia McWilliam) and a lot of interesting ideas to chew on (though they could have been explored a lot more), but I didn't feel much emotional connection to the stories or to much of the writing in general. This is especially the case with the novel - although there are some interesting ideas and writing in there, none of the characters really come to life for me and the way they're written makes them seem wooden and unreal. That's a pretty big negative here, considering how well-written many of the short stories were. It's not all bad though, with some fun little nuggets from fiction writers such as Peter Carey and Simon Armitage. I'm not going to write a full review because there are already a few hundred reviews up there already, just wanted to point out that it might not be worth buying for the price and that the short story collections are much more engaging. There's a lot of really good stuff in here, but it's best not to buy the big boxset to get it all. A great deal for the short story collections, but if you're after the whole New Writing 3, I'd recommend buying them separately, they're better than the whole. Dave and Norm Lagasse two bushy-bearded brothers in their forties are sitting in their modest home in Santa Fe in New Mexico USA and reliving their childhood. In front of them lies a wooden board covered in round plastic pieces. Dave and Norm sit on the couch, and look at the table, and say to each other, “Let's see what our mother did to us last night”. Dave and Norm, are boys, in their forties now, and they grew up with this game called Checkers. They were the only children in their family, and their mother would buy them the game, and then let them play for hours on end. She would sit at the kitchen table and watch them, and their behavior, become very funny, and at times, strange. As they reminisce, they are both having a hearty chuckle, and their mother and father are in the kitchen, where it was silent, and quiet, and a deep silence prevailed. Dave says, “Last night, we got in a little trouble for breaking the rules.” Norm and Dave continue, “Well, we were playing for money. This was our second chance to play for money. Given this story: Careless tourists scar ancient alpine rock art Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being gradually destroyed. Scientists and researchers fear that the 36000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so [line 6: beginning] rapidly that they will not survive for future generations. "They are doing irreparable damage to this beautiful alpine site by not cleaning it up," Professor Robert J. Bagnall, of the French National Institute of Anthropology and History, told a French news channel. "To think that these are our ancestors and that they leave such things for future generations to see... we must be very worried." Tourists have flocked to Mont Bego to view a range of works, including a series of images of a man and two animals which were believed to depict the Roman emperor Nero. Other rock carvings at the site include images of a horse and a shepherd, and a tree covered in images of birds, animals, fruit, flowers and vines.      "It's almost a religious experience," one British tourist, Ian Campbell, told the Daily Telegraph newspaper.      But the rocks are not untouched: they have a long and colorful history which began thousands of years ago, when people living in the Alps began carving stones and peeling back bark to make pictures in rock. The first rock paintings appeared at Mont Blanc in the Alps around 800, before spreading north. The Romans were fascinated by the art and wrote about the rock carvings, although historians disagree about the exact meaning of many of the images. The artists who carved the drawings also left behind tools, or "paintbrushes" as some have called them, which allowed researchers to work out what was being depicted and how it was created..

First Impressions Are Often Lasting Ones

Studies show that people form impressions of us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe how we dress, our eye contact, body language and our speaking volume and tone of voice. We often take our first impressions for granted, thinking that they will stick and that the way we present ourselves at work will reflect the way we'll present ourselves at home or with our friends.  However, the way you present yourself is always changing. You should learn to communicate as effectively and efficiently as possible for your job, but your personal style should also evolve over time. Start by changing your clothes by wearing clothes that will improve your image. If you've never worn business clothes before, you may want to buy some suits or dresses that you can try on and try on at home. You should also wear a new pair of shoes once in a while. This will help improve the way your foot steps in public.

Talking too loud and too quickly
Talking too loud and too quickly will make others feel uneasy and uncomfortable around you. You may be seen as a person who is out of control and unprofessional.  To lower your voice, try to speak with a low volume, and speak slower. Take the time to make sure you are speaking to the person directly and clearly. If you need to talk more quickly, then talk at the speed of conversation.

Speak too slowly

Given this story: Over the past fifteen years my research has documented that for many online life and smartphone connections have got in the way of things that people feel are important. We're so busy communicating that we don't have time to think we don't have time to sit down and have a conversation. It's that time of the year again when most of us are going to be glued to the TV and computer, trying to out-do our friends on Facebook and Twitter. We may try and convince ourselves that we aren't a part of the "Digital Divide," that we have access to all the same information, just through a different mode of communication. We know that the real divide is access to time, and in many cases, money. It's easy for us to believe that the new digital age means a more equal and less divided world. It means a world where any person with a computer and an internet connection can have a job, sell their creative work on the web, or simply make a friend across the world. It sounds like a simple equation. All they have to do is get a job and start a blog, and they can be the center of the world. In this equation, the first part is very important. The employer needs to recognize the value of the blog; the company needs to be able to pay the bills, hire the people, and afford the infrastructure needed to operate a blog. To put it another way, a blog is not free. And so the next few years will be spent learning how to make money with a blog, and how to balance working on it with working a job. When it comes to news, there’s more than you can shake a stick at. That's the problem for a variety of reasons. First, while it’s certainly easy to get caught up in news stories across a wide range of topics – from the latest celebrity gossip to an in-depth look at the presidential election – we’re in the information age and, to some extent, we’re living in a golden age for news. It’s a never-ending stream of news. And this deluge comes with an uncomfortable side effect: There’s just too much to keep up with, to absorb, to keep track of. Given this story: Trying to get published? If you are wondering where to send your story our expert Margaret Stubbs is here with the advice you need. Readers of this magazine often write in saying 'I have written this story / book. This year’s theme for the Bookmark is The Longer Story: a call to writers to use the power of long form narrative to tell more engaging, satisfying stories. What I love best about reading a book is how the author is able to take a complex concept or relationship and turn it into a long-form story that allows the reader to see their relationship to the topic from a new angle. This is what books do so well: they help us look at the world in a different way. The power of the long form story extends beyond books, however. When the short story was invented, the idea of a short story was limited, because short stories were usually a single event. As we move into the novel, however, the short story has the potential to be much more complex, as a form allows the storyteller to explore ideas through characters, scenes and plot. One of the strengths of the short story is that it allows the author to play with the form and allow the reader to feel a certain degree of freedom. This is something that the novel often does not do: the reader is given specific instructions and sometimes they just have to stick to them. In both short stories and novels, the short story and the novel work in a similar way. Short stories and novels are very much about the details of each story: which character is doing what, what is that person doing next? The idea that the reader has, is that these are the 'facts'.

Given this story: Careers Advice You're not happy in your job at the moment but you don't know how to change? Kitty Doherty gives some good advice. The answer for more and more people who want to change their job is to turn to a careers adviser. You will be asked to write a brief history of yourself and then sit through a number of tests known as 'psychometrics'. My friends and I were discussing the advice that we had received from careers advisers when we were at school. I realised that while I thought it was really good advice when I was younger, I don't think I really took much note of it at the time, maybe because I was so busy going on about my life, and what I wanted to do with it. When you ask someone for advice, it is easy to get all caught up in the detail of the advice you receive, and lose sight of what the point of the advice is. After all, the advice is only advice if you take it, and you will only be able to take it if it is right for you. So when you ask for career advice, it is important to think about what the goal of the advice is. If the advice is 'you should become a teacher', then you need to decide whether you actually want to be a teacher. If the advice is 'you should be a surgeon', then you need to decide whether you want to become a surgeon. This isn't always as easy as it seems though, as our job, and the things that drive us, can change in the course of our lives. The first question you need to answer, is whether you want to become a careers adviser. This article has been reproduced in a new format and may be missing content or contain faulty links. Given this story: Where I get my energy Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the full to tell us how they do it. A. Jeanette Kupfermann Journalist and author: 'I think it's excitement. I've got to be doing something that's a challenge. If I'm absorbing something new and learning I get tremendous energy. The most valuable thing for women in my experience is a good life partner, a partner that is as interested in life as you are. I'm a very restless person, I like new things. My husband will spend months trying to figure out where my next career is going to be. So I think that in my life the most important thing is my husband because he's so into life. I'm probably more practical than he is. I know where my next meal's coming from. I know who I'm with. But I think what's important is knowing that you're not alone and that you've got a partner that's just as into it as you are. It's a lot of pressure on women to have it all together. I think if you have a partner that understands and is a good person, and is really, really good, it's very important. As a mother of three, I was often told that being a mother was the best thing I could do, and it's true. But then people would say things like, "You'll never be a career woman." I said, "If I wanted to be a career woman, I'd go back to school and get a master's in the subject." They say, "But it's so hard to have a good career, with kids." I'll tell you what's hard: being a mother with children in the school system. So it's a very fine line. I want to have a great career..

Given this story: Confident people what's their secret? Confident people may look as though they were born that way but most will tell you that it's a skill they've learned because they had to. Nina Hathway asks five people how they did it. A Jenny When I left school I was very shy and I always thought I'd stay that way. I used to get made fun of all the time. I was told I had poor social skills, was arrogant, and had a'stiff upper lip' - a phrase which has no relevance whatsoever in terms of being a shy person. When I say 'I used to' - it wasn't a very positive experience! But I've worked out how to manage it and I can be quite outgoing now. The thing that's changed the most in my life is the internet. I've learned so much about human behaviour by spending so much time online. I can read a lot of websites like this, Psychology Today or even websites for specific companies to see if they really have what they promise. And I do try to be as careful as I can when I'm using the internet to avoid being a bad influence on younger people - even if it means I'm a little paranoid about it. I'm only 23 but I've had my entire world opened up to me and I think I might have changed as a person as a result.     I used to feel that I had to put on a performance at all times - no matter what I was doing I had to make sure I looked as though I was doing the thing, as though I were enjoying it. Given this story: Trills and bills If there's one thing guaranteed to send tears running down your cheeks it's the sight of a brilliant child collecting a medal. Julia Gregson asked three young stars and their mothers to describe some of the pleasures and pains of their lives. A. Annika Reeder 15 won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. Her mother is a nurse, her father drives buses for the government in a town of about 20,000, and her brothers are 14 and 12. Yet, at 17, Annika Reeder is a national treasure of Australia. “She gets more letters than me and everyone else combined,” says Julie Gregson, the Australian Olympic Committee president. In February, she won the country’s top athletic achievement, the gold medal in the women’s gymnastics individual all-around at the Commonwealth Games in the Gold Coast. She did so with the grace and skill of a gymnast of 25, the strength of a 27-year-old and the poise of a 17-year-old. “Every time she steps on the field, she looks like a champion,” says her coach, Glenn Barrie, who trained the great Anncy Seiter, Australia’s greatest gymnast, and now trains Ms. Reeder, the best gymnast in the country. “In the gym she does it on a much, much, higher level. She’s a special case,” Mr. Barrie says. “Some girls are lucky enough to be the best girl in their region or school. Annika is the best girl in Australia.” A teenager’s life can be hard enough, and an athlete’s even harder. So, too, for teenagers without parents around. And so is.

The kingfisher’s habitat is wetland, scrubland or heathland, and will be found in rivers, streams, ponds and wet meadows, feeding on fish.  The species is considered to be declining in the UK, and its breeding range has already been largely reduced.

Given this story: Studio Audiences What's it like to be in the audience when a television programme is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Like technical difficultiesstudio audiences are just another common feature of television lifeand yet to many of us they remain a mystery. Watching them getting excited on game shows for example we sit back and ask ourselves - just who are these people? It is, according to the script, the moment of truth. In the next 30 seconds, the contestants of I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here will find out whether they are going to be eaten or not, and if they are they'll be in the knowledge that at least two hundred million people are watching, along with hundreds of commentators and millions of others on satellite, mobile phones and computers. It's huge, and it's a big deal. There will be phone-in questions, and the panel are likely to be nervous. The contestants must have their heads down, be focused, act brave, and have no emotion at all. And they have just two minutes and thirty-five seconds. The pressure is huge. Even though most of us have little clue what goes on in a TV studio, we are somehow able to judge the contestants in a way that an on-air personality can never dream of.  For those of us who love TV drama, it's almost sacrilegious to talk about watching the studio audience. When we talk about watching TV drama we mean the drama at the bottom of the screen, not the drama on the top. The drama in the bottom, where the cast and crew are creating the work we see on the top, that we love and that takes us away to somewhere wonderful. But the drama at the bottom, where the cameras record the work of the writers and producers, is often the best drama we have. We get to see.

Hodgkin was born in Kent in 1897, one of six children of a coal miner and his wife. Her sister, Margaret, became a professional chemist. Her father worked in the pits at Dartford during the wars, but moved the family to the village of Rotherfield when they were safe again. Hodgkin went to an all-girls school in nearby Ashford. She excelled at English, and was soon teaching it to children in the local village. Then she set about devising and building her own chemistry set. She won a scholarship to Exeter when she was 16, but she also had a year studying medicine at Reading, then she joined a chemistry club. She also learned how to make her own equipment. Janson, who has had work displayed in numerous art exhibitions and fairs worldwide, says she can't sleep, can't eat properly and is unable to concentrate on her normal work. She says the crime has left her traumatised and she feels angry and vulnerable at the way she felt she was targeted. She told the BBC's Today programme "There are no words that can describe how this feels and what it does to you. I feel very vulnerable. I feel very angry at how I felt I was vulnerable. Given this story: New In Paperback A. The career of citizen Tristan Smith set in the fictional republic of Efica is an extraordinary parable of human power history and humour. In a feat of considerable literary skill the author has created a world with its own history traditions and customs. Tristan Smith is an average man who wakes one day to find himself an alien in the body of a professional secret agent. In a story of far-fetched events and high adventure, Smith must confront his own inner conflicts, as well as a ruthless KGB who wants him dead. The central theme of human relationships is explored through many complex and interesting characters, including a police chief, an evil spy, an alien, and a young, beautiful woman with a tragic past. The story is told with Smith’s narration.  As the main character, Tristan Smith, I had to speak a lot; a lot of my dialogues are directly spoken out to the reader; in fact, the majority of the characters are. I believe I succeeded in bringing out the atmosphere of the story, though it was difficult. I think the book’s main weakness is its repetitive structure. I sometimes found it rather boring, but I tried to write a lot to bring variety and change the pace, and not to repeat the same dialogue.  Tristan Smith’s career is a unique, exciting and emotional saga that captures the imagination and captures the hearts of its readers. A must read for everyone! Given this story: Career Power Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take full control at work. A. What makes a good leader? A leader is one who inspires an agent of change a developer who shows the way forward. Leadership is not about breeding or height - taller being better as the early theorists believed. A successful leader is one who creates a culture that allows for change. Culture is about the way of life within an organisation. It is all about how people see each other, how they act and how they communicate. If you don’t have a great culture, you will lack the key ingredients of an effective leader. You can’t force others to accept or adopt new ways of working without setting the right cultural environment. You need a culture where individuals are free to innovate and risk taking. You also need a culture that supports the creation of new ideas and new ways of working. Your culture has an important impact on your individual as well as your team’s success. Everyone in your organisation needs to understand that culture is important and the need to develop and shape it. If a group’s culture is not working, don’t assume that it is the individual who is the problem. Rather, take a step back and look at your own actions and behaviours, you may have contributed to the problems in the culture by not challenging the status quo. 1. Recognise that culture is a collaborative process. Culture cannot just be created by one person or in one team, it takes a lot of work. The best leaders take ownership of developing the culture and make everyone in the organisation feel included in the process. Leaders have to recognise that their own personal feelings and beliefs are irrelevant. Instead, they have to focus on making sure the culture is.

Given this story: Careers Six people talk about their typical working day A. Credit Card Executive I get up at 6 am to arrive at the office around 7.30 am. I manage all the customer development programmes for our regular credit card users. My responsibilities include the launch and management of the Membership Rewards scheme in the major European markets. After the initial set-up period, I focus entirely on the key accounts, and that means talking to our card issuers and the banks in those markets about how we might expand the offer and drive more new sales. I also have to meet regularly with all our key account holders to discuss new product offers and new distribution approaches. I then head off to the office, where I have a meeting with my direct reports to discuss our progress to date, so they know our priorities, and the challenges we will face over the next 24 hours. This gives me some sense of which people to ask for help, and which projects to oversee. I then jump on a team WhatsApp group to continue the discussions about how we can deliver new ways of engaging with our customers, and I’m generally in and out of the office throughout the day, having one-to-one meetings with people on new projects and new products. By the time I head home around 5pm, I’m exhausted, so I usually spend the evening writing and designing my email newsletter for the team. 2. You have the power to control how you work and how much you do.: This is a great opportunity to make the most of what you do. Given this story: Sound the Alarm Stuart Harris reports Many of us listen to the radio when we get up in the morning and most of us also require some external means to persuade us to get out of bed. Thus we have the clock radio. But how do you pick a good one? The Best Clock radio for Bed You’re probably sitting there wondering what the point of a clock radio is? The truth is, as much as your device is meant to keep track of time, a clock radio can also help you wake up in the mornings. Your alarm may be loud enough for you to hear it in the night. However, when you wake up, you might not be fully aware of what time it is. If you have a clock radio, you can hear your alarm clock ringing in the other room before you even get out of bed. This helps ensure you don’t miss your alarm, and you can get right out of bed to start your day. Most clock radios also include a small speaker, so you can easily listen to an alarm clock radio to go off when you get up in the morning. There are many different features available when it comes to clock radios. Some include FM radio, the ability to set a particular song as the alarm, and even the ability to create a special alarm for a specific time. Once you buy a clock radio for bed, your next concern will be choosing what features will work for you. Consider your needs: Do you want a radio with a speaker? I HAD a most peculiar period of my life when I didn’t have any summers. When I was in university in the ’60s, our summer camp was in New Zealand, in the very north. It was summer for half the year in Britain and winter for another half. One of the reasons we went there was that the school I studied at was the first in the country to do a full course in permaculture, so the school grounds were very naturally planned. Some of the students went down in the winter to work in Australia in a banana plantation. On one of my visits down to visit my family, I went down to the grounds with them and saw how it worked. It was a fantastic idea. There was a whole lot of fruit growing there.  The New Zealand student came back and did a course on permaculture in the same place. The next summer we set off for New Zealand. The reason I tell this story is that the course was on the basis of ecological design. That was an unusual idea at the time, but it has been adopted by many people. We went down to the school’s grounds at the beginning of the course. It was a very simple permaculture course. We looked at the land and made a map of it, laid down our plans of how it should be developed. We then went down to look for native plants and ferns and things that would work in that environment. We believe in getting the best value from our trips. We set high standards for ourselves in respect of food, accommodation, facilities and the way we interact with local people. She has been writing since she was a girl, but she took the name P.D. James when she married the novelist James. The mystery writer, in her first novel, was a woman who, by day, worked as a social worker; in her spare time, she enjoyed gardening. James decided to put his wife in her proper literary role and, in the course of his first book, Murder by Contract, it turns out that she is brilliant and inventive, and that she is in reality a writer. He wrote under the name of P.D. James because it sounded so much better. The public agreed with his choice because James' works have become immensely popular.  The mystery writer has since published many books and is regarded by her colleagues as the best crime writer in Britain.  P.D. Given this story: DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS? We asked five leading British publishers about the effect of the reviews of a book on its commercial success. Here is what they said. Publisher A Reviews are absolutely key for publishers - the first part of the newspaper we turn to. We've been doing book reviews in print for nearly 150 years, so it is no surprise that publishers recognise the role that book reviews can play in helping readers decide whether to buy a book.  It's also no surprise that publishers would like to know how their books are being reviewed - they want to find out how the book is being described by the people who most regularly review books. Booksellers are another group to whom book reviewers owe their livelihoods, so it seems sensible that book reviewers want to know what booksellers are saying about their books. So, as the new year approaches and we look forward to reading the best books of 2015, it seems only logical that we try to find out what booksellers are saying about them.  What happens when a publisher or bookseller makes a negative review public? We asked five leading British publishers about the effect of the reviews of a book on its commercial success. Here is what they said.  In many ways, book reviewers have it easier than booksellers because their reviews are not part of an entire book being put on sale, but they have some of the same problems. Booksellers have to deal with books from publishers whose books are currently out of print or whose booksellers' stocks are low - which means that if booksellers are unimpressed, the booksellers' accounts may suffer. Book reviewers are more likely to use their reviews to talk about a book they want to see more.

My quest to climb the Seven Summits came late in life. I will take them in the order of my climbing them. A. Mt. Mt. Elbrus, the highest point in Eastern Europe, is often described as the most beautiful mountain in Europe, but I had never climbed it, nor even seen it. Having just turned 60, and after a life of doing jobs that left me little time for any passion, it seemed like the time was right. On December 31, 2012, I left my home in San Diego, California, and took a 10-hour overnight train for Moscow, followed by a 2-day bus trip to Minsk, Belarus, to catch a flight to Kiev, then a 12-hour plane ride to Baku, Azerbaijan, and a 16-hour flight to Istanbul, Turkey, before arriving in Istanbul early the next morning. I rented a car and traveled south to the border town of Trabzon. There, I rented a motorcycle and started the 3-day trip to Elbrus. While the motorcycle would not have been good for the steep rocky roads that traverse the mountain, it was good for touring with friends who didn’t speak Russian well, as the motorcycle was one of those cars with a small trunk. I had never been on a motorcycle and found myself being towed along the narrow roads of Trabzon, with occasional stops for gas or to check out the sights. After passing through the border town of Aktau, I reached the border crossing into the Republic of North Ossetia, which is not recognized by the United Nations or Russia,.

I can picture the man or woman in the job interview, who’s been asked for a sample, trying to find some elegant, graceful line, or perhaps a neatness of penmanship reminiscent of the Royal Mail’s official stationery. The employer then might well ask whether she is emotionally stable enough to take on the responsibility of dealing with customers. It is hard to argue that the actual contribution to development amounts to a great deal directly. “Voluntary work is not an object of charity but an act of self-sacrifice in the field of human development.” — William R. Broad      Voluntary work by people in international organizations or with NGOs is essential for improving human conditions in poor countries. According to the World Health Organization, 1 million of the 5 million new deaths in 2001 were preventable. That is why volunteerism in the field of global development is increasing. Volunteering by doctors and teachers can drastically reduce the death rate. In the field of water management and sanitation, volunteer work is a crucial resource, as volunteers provide expertise to developing countries.      Voluntary work in the field of international development can be divided into different types of volunteering. Each type offers the opportunity to meet people in another country, learn about their culture and customs, and develop a closer relationship with local people.      Volunteerism in education and healthcare is one of the most important types of international volunteer work, which plays an integral role in the process of development. The purpose of education and healthcare work is not only to provide skills and knowledge but also to provide people with emotional support. Volunteer doctors and nurses not only provide basic healthcare services to the needy but also play a role in the promotion of human values in people. In addition, volunteer nurses also teach new medical technologies to the local communities. This not only alleviates pressure on the healthcare system but also stimulates economic development in poorer countries.

The University Museum of Classical Archaeology The Museum of Classical Archaeology is one of the few surviving collections of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture in the world comprising over six hundred works. The first thing to remember about the collection is that nothing here is genuine. All the sculptures are accurate replicas cast from the originals mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology, founded in 1873, houses one of the largest collections of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture in the world. The Museum has two floors, on the first floor are Greek sculpture works, on the second floor Roman sculpture and bronze objects. The first floor also contains many Greek statues of the gods and goddesses, and bronze objects of ancient Greece, on the second floor there are also bronzes and other antiquities from the Roman Empire. Both the museum and the University Library have a good collection of books on ancient Greek sculptures, with a special emphasis on Roman sculpture and Greek mythology. The museum’s collections are very rich in terms of both artistic diversity and antiquity. The museum houses not only works from Greece and Rome, but also objects from Asia Minor, Turkey, Egypt and Palestine.  In its initial years, the collection consisted mainly of Greek sculptures. In 1910 the first Roman collection was added, and a collection of ancient Turkish and Arabic sculptures was added in the early 1940’s. In 1960 the Museum’s original foundation collection of Greek sculptures was donated to the museum by the Kallias family. The museum has always displayed these sculptures in their original position, so the visitor can easily see the exact position of the sculpture as it looked in ancient Greece or Rome. Given this story: Are you too nice for your own good? When I had my first job as a waitress in a restaurant I soon learnt that the best way to get myself out of trouble was to smile sweetly at every possible opportunity. 'I'm so sorry' I beamed when I dropped the plate on the floor and it smashed into smithereens. I know what you mean, I'm a bit of a chatterbox when I'm nervous. Once, I managed to talk the local constabulary straight into arresting my ex-boyfriend after I found him trying to steal our daughter's teddy bear (a huge, well-loved treasure). I didn't find out for a week. I was so worried. But eventually he broke down and confessed to everything. So don't worry about it. And try not to be so nice... The last time I was so nice was when I found out my grandmother had a terminal disease. She only had a few months left, and the last thing she said to me was that she hated being ill and didn't want to be a burden. She passed away a few months later. I'm sorry you went through that, but at least you could still see her face one last time, smiling at you. Sometimes, the only way out of a hard situation is just to get out of it. Try not to worry about what others think. We all have our own problems. And you did the best you could to help. Don't worry about being too nice, in the end, you'll only put yourself in more trouble. If I can suggest a bit of a compromise, try not to be too nice to people when you're nervous. Maybe that's what's happened here. You're too soft. Anyway, you've already taken that step to confess.

Given this story: Science flying in the face of gravity Journalist Tom Mumford joins students using weightlessness to test their theories. It looked like just another aircraft from the outside. The pilot told his young passengers that it was built in 1964 a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker based on the Boeing 707 passenger craft. What looks like a giant piece of wood took off in weightlessness. Inside was the NASA-funded 'Newton Laboratory', a two-floor steel-tube aircraft with two engines mounted at the ends of its fuselage. Its walls are painted an eerie dark red to hide the fact that it is actually a full-sized research aircraft. Inside the cabin was a team of nine students, most of them just teenagers, and three senior staff from the University of Southampton, in Southampton, UK, which funded the flight.      It was meant to be their first successful weightless flight. Instead, it became a sort of flying scientific experiment, testing the effects of weightlessness on the human body and proving that some theories about the nature of gravity, like the ones advanced in the 1800s by British physicist Isaac Newton, can be tested in weightlessness.      As far as Newton was concerned, gravity wasn't something that acted in one direction. It was an acceleration caused by mass and nothing else, and that acceleration was due to gravity acting directly on every object, no matter how far apart they were.      However, some scientists argue that gravity, like the force that pulls a cup of tea toward your lips, is affected by the geometry of the object or body.      The students in the Newtons Laboratory, known as the 'Newtons Seven', took part in a series of experiments to find out if that is true.

The day I drew Picasso Richard Cork recalls how as an 78-year-old student he came face-to-face with one of the most revered artists of the century. Even seen at a distance eating his lunch at an open-air restaurant in Cannes, the painter was instantly recognisable. I was an I8-year-old student filling in time before university by travelling round Europe and Morocco in a battered and unreliable van.      The drawing I made of him was a copy, but in that moment my imagination was blown and I had created a masterpiece. For decades it was the only portrait I had made and I treasure it above my many more pictures.      I was not aware that Picasso was such a character. It certainly surprised me to see an ageing man enjoying a meal at an outdoor cafe. It was also an absolute shock to be seated next to one of the greatest artists of the century. He had no concept of personal space, only the illusion that he and his famous paintings and drawings were the only things that existed.      We had finished eating and Picasso, clearly bored, began to sketch and draw us. In an hour he had created 15 drawings. I sat enthralled, as he explained the different characteristics of his famous girls, each with their own story. He talked of all the different moods and thoughts he could evoke in his girls.      He also began to talk.

Advertising started to plummet early in 1989 well before the recession really began to bite. Advertising's problems are more fundamental and the decline is worldwide. The unhappy truth is that advertising has failed to keep up with the pace of economic change. Many studies have shown that advertising is ineffective. A large number of studies are done that are inconclusive. The study above is the most rigorous study I have found. It shows the importance of advertising. It found advertising increases the likelihood of making purchase decisions. And that the increase is dramatic. Advertising can actually improve the purchase decision. If a woman sees an ad for a pair of panty hose, the likelihood is higher than her being in a crowded store looking for panty hose. She has learned something about the product and the price is likely to be right. Advertising can even increase the likelihood of people being in the store. I don't know about you, but when I see an advertisement, I am immediately in the store with my cart. I am thinking about what would look good in that size, and where. Given this story: NATURAL TALENTS In the mere seven million years since we humans separated from chimpanzees we haven’t had time to develop any differences: genetically we’re still more than 98 per cent identical to chimps. On this grand evolutionary scale whatever it is that separates humans from animals is a very recent development. And yet we can make great differences in the time it takes for our minds to do something. When we get together with a group of people we can invent a language in a matter of hours, and even the most limited number of humans working together can create a vast number of new tools, both physical and intellectual. The most extraordinary examples of this happen during the development of musical skills. You can start to play a musical instrument within hours and you can learn to read music within a few days. This is incredible when you think about it. A complete new human brain being created in just a matter of days, when previously a complete human brain would take years if not decades to form. And this is not just limited to musical ability; there are many other areas in which there is a dramatic difference between humans and other animals. We have the ability to think critically, make decisions and form opinions, which is not the case for most animals. We can also experience emotion like a human being, and therefore we can have a sense of humour, and make jokes, which is not the case for many of the other animals. We also have the ability to become physically stronger, and the ability to control what happens in our bodies when we move. In short, we can form new aspects of ourselves quickly and completely depending on what we are doing. As we explore deeper into the universe and start to understand its structure we’re going to learn more and more about what it is.

The end of print may take some time: Peter Preston Transition. It’s a pleasant word and a calming concept. Change may frighten some and challenge others. But transition means going surely and sweetly from somewhere present to somewhere future. Unless that is it is newspapers’ ‘transition’ to the online world, an uncertain and highly uncomfortable process – because frankly it may not be a process at all.      The UK newspaper industry may seem more stable than, say, the Italian print publishing industry. But this is hardly the case. Newspapers, like all media, face a very different set of pressures to the ones which had been faced by magazines. Many magazines are thriving online, many are thriving in print, but in a world of advertising and social media, few are thriving – even in print – at the same rate as they did in the past. For newspapers, the changes in advertising and audience have been happening for a long time, and are not going to stop any time soon. What is to be done about it?      To start with, newspapers should get to grips with the digital transition. Some of them are doing this, some are still waiting. That’s no good. Newspaper publishers ought to be thinking, as far ahead as possible, about the next thing. The problem, it seems to me, is that most are still trying to solve the problems of yesterday and the day before. This is not.

Given this story: The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from perfectly crafted furniture Joanna Watt meets him Charles Hurst gives the impression of being a man in a hurry. I arrive at his workshop tucked under a railway arch in East London and am greeted with a quick handshake and the words: 'Well fire away then!' Whether this brusqueness is real or a front hiding a shy streak is not immediately apparent. As he works on a sofa, Hurst lifts a leg and bends it in several different directions, creating a sense of movement and action. As he works, his face is almost as alive as the thing he is carving. He has a light-blue scowl which seems almost impossible to escape. When I point out he may be in pain, he gives a sheepish grin and says he is not. Hurst, 75, doesn't suffer from arthritis and doesn't take any drugs. He lives alone in his small house in a suburb of London, and says his main concern in life is making furniture that pleases its owners. He has been carving since he was 11, when his father gave him his first chair to make after watching him work for three days.      'I was in heaven, my dad was in heaven,' he says. 'They had both seen me at my very, very best.' His father, a blacksmith, encouraged him to become a cabinet-maker and took him to showrooms. 'He was my mentor, he taught me everything that I knew. My father was a great craftsman.' In 1962, when he was 34, he set up on his own and moved to a purpose-built, 19th-century shop on the London road. The shop was well known for its excellent carpentry and furniture design, but the work was very low-key, as Hurst mostly dealt with wealthy people.   .

Given this story: Solar Survivor Charles Clover ventures inside Britain’s most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire is full of surprises. The first is Britain’s least-known ancient cathedral Southwell Minster celebrated by writers of an environmental disposition for the pagan figures of ‘green’ men which medieval craftsmen carved into the decoration in its thirteenth-century chapter house. It turns out the house’s most environmentally-friendly feature is not the absence of electricity or even of hot water, but, rather, the lack of doors. Built in the 14th century, the Minster is remarkable as one of the few surviving English cathedrals to have remained largely unchanged throughout the medieval era and into the Reformation. Its stone pillars, with their centuries-old carvings, are as beautiful and haunting as ever. Yet in keeping with its age, this part of Nottinghamshire has few modern conveniences. The Minster is therefore a rare oasis of conservation and quiet in a modern city. We pull up outside the Minster and Charles leads me into the oldest part of the building, the Chapter House, where we meet the cathedral librarian, Anne, and Anne’s younger brother, James, the librarian’s nephew. He has been doing his homework here before classes and after exams. Anne seems a warm and thoughtful lady – we talk for hours about the history and architecture of the Minster. Her house, which she lives in with her daughter and son-in-law, has no carpets – they have felt floors. And there’s no electricity. The old librarian’s daughter also lives in the Minster and brings their laundry. The building’s great hall is used for conferences, classes, weddings and funerals. And the Minster has a large, beautiful garden –.

The most obvious way to lure you back to the produce section is with the bright and early arrival of fruit and vegetables. The morning paper is often filled with pictures of the new and exciting produce found in the early morning hours. The idea being that fresh produce tastes better when its still young. The earliest strawberries, for example, are the sweetest and juiciest. It’s also why many fruits and vegetables (berries, berries and more berries) are often featured in newspaper ad inserts before noon. It’s also why there are often advertisements about shopping early in the week or mid-week. You know you’re more likely to see a picture of a salad or a freshly picked fruit on a Wednesday than a bag of chocolate chip cookies. 2. Produce sales are a big driver of sales at supermarkets. As such, you see more and more signs.

Given this story: Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives asleep. It seems certain therefore that sleep has a vital function. However what that function might be is still in debate. Scientists are far from being in agreement about precisely why so much of our precious time is given over to sleep. Sleep plays a crucial role in many life processes such as the growth of embryos, healing wounds and the formation of muscle and tissue. But the role of sleep in our everyday lives is still shrouded in mystery, say scientists who are still far from agreeing about precisely why so much of our precious time is given over to sleep. They are also not certain why sleep seems to fall out of our lives so suddenly, overnight, when it is usually a gradual process, according to the latest research published in the journal Nature. In a study of more than 800,000 participants in 18 countries, British scientists from the Royal United Services Institute said a healthy sleep quality was crucial for healthy mental and physical performance, as well as physical and mental recovery. For example, they found that inadequate sleep at night resulted in lower performance on short-term memory tests. The researchers also looked at data from more than 200,000 people in the United States, Britain, France, Italy, Poland and Japan over a period of 16 years. One theory put forward by the team of experts at the RUSI’s Sleep and Health Research Lab is that people can find sleep challenging at the best of times, and that when they are in a stressful situation or experiencing high levels of anxiety or stress, they struggle even more with sleep. However, the study also found that people’s sleep quality is also influenced by the amount of caffeine that they drink in the day. “We found that individuals.

Given this story: THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING I thought everyone would be pleased but one of my colleagues was absolutely furious. ‘What do you mean?’ she raged. ‘If it was that easy why didn’t you stop years ago?’ I suppose my inability to explain how one afternoon I had been a packet-a-day life-long smoker and four hours later I was not was faintly irritating. I found out the hard way that the only people who care if you stop smoking are other smokers. Everyone else just wants you to live long and healthy. It is very hard to explain to the public why it’s not just about the money but, as a human being, it’s nice knowing you are in control of your life. If I was a smoker I would love it if everyone could have it sorted like I have. To give up is difficult but, as I always say to people, it’s the easiest thing I’ve done in my life. While professional astronomers are still the world leaders in astronomy research and many of these stars will be visible to the unaided eye in the near future (perhaps not with the power and precision of, say, a planet-seeker telescope, but certainly with a small backyard telescope), astronomy has now spread to a much wider audience. Even the earliest known Greek fashion statement, the kylix, had a symbolic meaning. Given this story: Heritage The true meaning and significance of heritage is that it gives people and communities a genuine sense of connection with the past. Obviously we feel connected to our personal heritage usually we know who and what our grandparents were and we will have heard stories about how they lived. So this might be interesting, here is an article from a local paper in the UK about a woman who has decided to build a memorial to herself. I was fascinated at how it started. The idea first emerged when a newspaper columnist suggested that she would be better placed if a permanent memorial were erected to reflect on her life, however, her husband, Colin Crouch, is more convinced. However, their son disagrees that a stone should be erected and suggests that she take a holiday and have a proper rest to reflect on her achievements. When this doesn’t work she makes up her mind to build a life-size model of herself to stand in a garden, and in a letter to her son she outlines her plan and the reasons why she feels the need to build it. A copy of that letter is below. I think the idea is a novel one, a way of looking back on the past in a meaningful way and also a way of remembering how our family was formed. The story was widely reported as news but I doubt the couple have actually taken it forward with building the memorial.  This isn’t a view I would hold and it is one that I strongly disagree with. I have written about this previously in blog posts but I am still struck by how often people do not take enough time to consider the meaning behind what they are doing. We just don’t think through the impact what we are doing might have on the future or the people who are directly.

Othello The transfer to London from Stratford of an exceptional production of Shakespeare’s play Othello allows me to make amends for an unfair review that I wrote when the show opened last spring. Back then I complained that Ray Fearon was too young to play the title role and I was guilty of running down his acting.      The truth is that Fearon has matured into the character and it is now quite clear to me that there was a great deal wrong with my review. Fearon did indeed have a good performance when I saw the play last spring and he has remained solid and strong ever since. He is still a very strong young man and it is no longer true to say that his Othello is ‘unconvincing’. That was my original error. As a result I have changed my mind about Fearon and am going to give the actor a great deal more credit for the part in this production than I gave him a year ago.      There have been several excellent recent productions of Shakespeare’s Othello and I must take the opportunity to give my congratulations to the actor who played Othello in the BBC National Orchestra of Wales’ recent version of the play which won the 2011 Gold Medal Award from the Olivier Awards. Given this story: Observing Lions In the popular imagination lions hunting for food present a marvel of group choreography: in the dying light of sunset a band of stealthy cats springs forth from the shadows like trained assassins and surrounds its unsuspecting prey. The lions seem to be archetypal social animals rising above petty dissension to work together towards a common goal - in this case their next meal. But in a new study researchers at the University of British Columbia have found that the real dynamics of hunting by lions can be completely different from these depictions in Hollywood movies. "The way the movies depict lion hunts is generally wrong," said study researcher Ian Wilson from UBC. "We show that there is no such thing as a 'gaggle,' that's a common myth," Wilson said in a university news release. "And the male lions that 'gaggle' - like Tom Cruise in The Lion King - are actually rare, solitary cats." The researchers studied a video of a lion hunt from 2009 filmed in Kavango Desert, Botswana. They examined more than 8,000 seconds of footage recorded at the time and tracked every motion of every individual lion in that footage for six weeks. They found that each lion was a solitary hunter, as opposed to the stereotypical gang of lionesses. While some lions do work together as "gaggles" to hunt, those gaggles are made up of as many as 20 individual lions. The research could open up new opportunities for scientists studying the real behaviors of these predators. "We might not know something as vital as what the true dynamics of the lion's hunt are," Wilson added. "The fact that the males are solitary and the females work in 'gaggles' is something we didn't know before. And this means that we need to understand the dynamics of the whole group in order.
