Given this story: Garbage in garbage out Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems environmentally sound and economically sensible. It may not be. Some rituals of modern domestic living vary little throughout the developed world. One such is the municipal refuse collection: at regular intervals rubbish bags or the contents of rubbish bins disappear into the bowels of a special lorry and are carried away to the local tip. The garbage is piled high, and the lorry rumbles around the edges of the industrial estate with the rumble of its sirens, until all that is left is the lorry itself: a steel and wood contraption, with a door at one end and a trailer at the other. The lorry is a mobile garbage truck, which stops at the local tip, fills its enormous hopper with rubbish, and then heads off, presumably to another industrial estate, in a circle. The idea behind it is obvious: garbage gets piled up; the trucks drive past and pick it up again. How does that work?  One of the early experiments involved a system that the Guardian calls “recycling”. People in the London area were allowed to buy “compostable” bags that contained household waste. The bags themselves could be recycled, but they weren’t supposed to be. To be honest, I don’t really see the point. In theory, most people don’t buy “compostable” bags; that would mean more rubbish on the street, and that would be seen as bad. People don’t buy “compostable” plastic food containers; that would mean more rubbish on the streets. The government should have been thinking about this; instead, it gave us an extra tax on single-use plastics, with the result that everything now has a huge price tag.  So now.

Given this story: Goat Racing I was about to witness goat racing. Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I was fighting my way through ice-cream vans hordes of people food stalls and hot music singeing my eardrums. Even though the general movement was towards the racecourse I elbowed my way through the crowds in an effort to get a good pitch. “You’re not going to get a good view.” A familiar and unwanted remark from a racecourse usher. As though I didn’t know that. I have a right to a view, he is not my boss and he had clearly never been to this one. And yet I’ve been there many times and never complained about a bad view before, although maybe that is because I don’t like to complain in general. But I still feel like a child who just asked Santa for a new bike and Santa laughed. Except this is a racecourse. It’s one of the strangest sights I’ve ever seen and I was never a great fan of the horse race, either. It is a sport where the fastest animal is also the most intelligent. You’re betting on something that could jump from end to end of a long-boat or a tennis ball. You’re paying for the ability of your opponent to look smart rather than speed. And that is the problem. When you look at the fastest thing in the world, it isn’t something that is intelligent, it’s just quick. I know it’s not much to go on, but most of the races go off in less than five minutes. The 100m of a horse race, for example, goes off in four. The difference between these two things is just a few hundredths of a second..

Given this story: 0ral History The growing trend for historians to rely on oral evidence is not without its problems. It is naive to suppose that someone’s testimony represents a pure distillation of past experience for in an interview each party is affected by the other. I am not alone in having my doubts about the oral history profession. For example, the American Historical Association has called for an end to oral history collections at the Archives of American Art; the American Ethnographic Society has warned of the dangers of conflating “historians and ethnographers”; and there are concerns that the new generation of historians will not be interested in oral history, particularly as a source of evidence because, as they put it: “Historians, by virtue of their specialty, are in a distinct position from other members of the community who are more interested in personal histories.”      But I think they are missing something. Oral history has the potential to provide a valuable, if sometimes less polished, record of historical narratives as they were being shared in the past. Not that they are perfect records. As is obvious in listening to interviews conducted in different contexts, they have many shortcomings.      I think there is a distinction to be made between what I call the “form” of oral history, which consists of the historical accounts themselves as they are being shared in context, and the “content” of oral history, which consists of accounts that have been interpreted to provide a record of how people experienced past events. I am referring here to what are known as “interpretive accounts” or “interpreter” accounts. These are the most commonly found among oral history collections and.

When the people interviewed for the Oral History Project of the Federal Bureau of Investigation came to a bank robbery in San Francisco in the early 1900s, they were asked by the bank clerk what they did there. One of them replied, “We saw a play.” But they did not describe the play. Did they not want to make the robbery look like they were ordinary people and not professional criminals? This was an important event in the development of public opinion regarding organized crime, but it is not an important event in the history of the San Francisco stage.       But to me the most interesting part of the oral history was when the interviewer asked if they had heard of the play before. The person described it as a “tragic play” in which the characters were all fools. “Well,” he said, “there was some truth in the statement.”       Oral histories are rich sources of materials on human behavior. We will probably never reach the point in which people will record information in the same form as people did in the past. But I am sure that we can improve the quality of the information that we can find, by listening carefully, and by applying the best tools available to us. All of these categories are (in some form or other) built from the same sort of cultural assumptions and so the ways in which scientists, political theorists, religious people, moralists, and so on construct and theorize about the world differ significantly. Given this story: Sand Much as I admire sands miraculous ability to be transformed into useful objects like glass and concrete I am not a great fan of it in its natural state. To me it is primarily a hostile barrier that stands between a seaside car park and the water itself. It blows in your face gets in your sandwiches and swallows vital objects like car keys and coins. I often find myself on the beach trying to retrieve something lost during the previous day. Usually it is some trinket which I just lost track of and have now buried in the sand. When I try to get it out it is always a struggle, especially if it is something like a straw hat which I don't fancy tramping through knee-deep sand after it has been sitting in my bag on the beach for six hours. What I do find helpful is this nifty tool from the early 1800's, which not only is very simple to use but it also helps to keep my lost item in the sand. A lot of other things have been invented since the invention of the sand-holder but none has such a simple but very efficient function.  This sand-holder looks rather like a miniature windmill, although this isn't exactly how it works. Instead, this holder works by having a number of wheels at the bottom of the holder, which turn when the sand holder is tilted. The sand that is sucked into the holder is then deposited on the beach while the holder is turned. You can imagine that this is a very simple contraption which works by a principle quite similar to the one found in the 'golf ball' vacuums that are common in high end cleaning kits. This means that as long as there is enough sand available to turn the wheel the sand-holder will work quite efficiently. Sand-holders have become so common in the.

Given this story: Art on TV Why is it that television so consistently fails when it comes to programmes about the visual arts? Painting and sculpture should be natural subjects for the camera which has the ability to show a whole work of art then move in close to examine the details. My answer: There are a host of reasons why artists rarely get their work on TV, the most important, of course, is that, generally speaking, television is not a good vehicle for visual information. It is a visual medium, but it is not a sensory one: most people see with their eyes, and that information is often transmitted to the brain through the eye movements we do when watching television. A good example of this is advertising on television; in most cases the creative direction for the visual is dictated by marketing goals, which means the images presented onscreen are designed to be highly "sellable". Most television shows, including art programming, are produced without this sort of audience-centred consideration, and end up looking like adverts designed to maximize impact. The result is that most television art programmes look like commercial advertisements: a sequence of close-ups, a montage, with one or two actual works of art shown in the middle of the sequence. The reason that most television art shows look the way they do is that they have to. There is little reason to create something that looks good if it is simply going to be viewed for an hour every week. One thing I would like to see is television shows about the visual arts, which would allow artists to use the medium to do their work as they like. I would like to see artists taking the opportunity to tell us about their works, their inspirations, their ideas and how they work:.

Chances are that if you find two or more people together anywhere on earth they will soon be exchanging words. I don't like people who can count. It's one thing to figure out that a person can add up to six in his head, but what is all that other stuff about, anyway? Why is he so sure that the sixth number he adds up is going to add up to seven? Maybe seven is the only number in which he can get it right, or maybe seven is the only number in which he can add up to at all. I really don't care. It's only six in his head, anyway. So let's all get back to the business of counting because our species has come to rely on it - not only to help people keep track of things, but to understand how to use things. There is absolutely no way to know, for instance, what kind of life you or I would lead without language, and in turn there is nothing more interesting or rewarding in our life than knowing that a living thing in another part of the world knows something we don't. But language is so tightly woven into human experience that it is scarcely possible to imagine our life without it, nor is there anything in our life more interesting or rewarding than knowing that a living thing in another part of the world has been able to use language to express herself or himself.      So we must keep at it - learn to count, so we can get the full benefit of our ability to communicate. It's not just about the numbers anymore - it's about the connections between them.

Given this story: Kinetic Art Rejoice — the well-nigh impossible has happened: London’s austere Hayward Gallery has been transformed into a place full of wonder. And not thankfully by some huge-budget mega-hyped multi-media extravaganza but by a charmingly idiosyncratic investigation into an almost forgotten aspect of the last 60 years. A new exhibition traces the history of kinetic art — that is art which is concerned with movement — in the twentieth century. A well-nigh impossible has happened. The well-nigh impossible has happened: London’s austere Hayward Gallery has been transformed into a place full of wonder. And not gladly by some huge-budget mega-hyped multi-media extravaganza but by an charmingly idiosyncratic investigation into an almost forgotten aspect of the last 60 years. A new exhibition traces the history of kinetic art — that is art which is concerned with movement — in the 20th century. The show, called Kinetic Art Rejoice, is curated by the French art historian Sophie Verdière, who has also done books on artists such as Alber Elbaz. She has written that the “development of kinetic art can be traced from the very beginnings of postwar modernism in the United States to Japan and the UK, where it quickly found its home, thanks to a new generation of international artists and scientists”. It sounds complicated — and it is, though not necessarily because of all the moving parts. Verdière has put together an exhibition of 50 objects, mostly found in private and institutional collections. They range from the relatively simple — a bicycle wheel — to the highly abstract — a pair of electric motors spinning an intricate propeller. In between are paintings, photographs and videos. They range in size from a few centimetres to a few tens of metres. You might see this exhibition as the high point of the last half-century in British.

Given this story: POETRY RECITALS At any given time in history the literary scene will seem confused to those who are living through it and it is the selectivity of posterity that makes the pattern and orders of eminence appear clearly defined to the retrospective view. In the next room, my parents were watching television. Dad was talking about the "mixed signals" sent by that same show, about the "inherent contradictions" within it. "It's a show about a dysfunctional family," he said, "so you can't expect it to be about good family values. It's supposed to be entertaining!"  I stared at him, silently protesting. This was not the conversation that I'd hoped to have, not right now. Not when I was home alone and a flood of emotions was raging within me. "Look, Dad," I said. "The people on that show are not really acting."  Dad didn't look up. He was studying a commercial, or maybe something on the Food Network, or maybe one of those "how to live your life" videos on the internet. But it didn't matter if he looked up or if he heard me. It wasn't me who was in the room at that moment, was it?  I felt myself blushing as I tried to figure out what to say next, so I just said, "You know what I think?" And then I told him what I'd done, what I'd read on the internet.  I'd been reading about the difference between poetry and prose. The difference between a poem and a short story. The difference between a biography and a memoir, and what these mean to the people who write them. It was all pretty interesting,.

Given this story: CRYING Charles Darwin thought that the human tendency to cry had no obvious evolving purpose. He was almost certainly wrong. More recently scientists have pointed to its social significance with psychiatrist John Bowlby highlighting the role of crying in developing the attachment between mother and child. Many believe that tears at least during childhood are mainly an expression of helplessness. Crying is an innate human behaviour. Evolutionists say our primary motivation for crying is to help other people to empathise with our feelings and to feel less helpless. But it turns out crying is so much more than that: our very instincts for crying may have evolved to help us cope with life's stresses and come out on the other side stronger and wiser. This week's study published in Nature journal found that mothers of human children produce many more tears than they did 20 years ago. Researchers from the University of British Columbia followed mothers and their children for up to 35 years. Their findings show that for mothers there are two significant periods during a child's early life: one of "tenderness", where crying is likely to be emotional rather than physical, and one of "mature emotional response" where it may be less easy for mothers to control their emotions. The researchers say that tears are produced in response to a number of different things. First, the mother's fear of abandonment might come through the release of tears. Or she may feel vulnerable as her child is growing up and feel the need to cry to get her strength back. According to evolutionary theorist Steven Pinker, the "visceral" emotional response of crying, the part of our brain that responds physically to the experience of pain, is something that's been ingrained in us since we first emerged from the ocean. When the first primate evolved from an amphibian, its ancestors developed a nervous system that allowed them.

Given this story: Blogging: Confessing to the world Some time ago a website highlighted the risks of public check-ins – online announcements of your where-abouts. The site’s point was blunt: you may think you are just telling the world ‘Hey I’m at this place’ – but you are also advertising your out-and-about-ness to all kinds of people everywhere – not all of them people you might like to bump into. This brings me to the current topic of Blogging in general. I am sure that most of us have become habitual in posting our thoughts on the web and how we feel about it. In doing so we are exposing ourselves to a very large pool of people; the problem we all need to consider is where those people might live and work and how much they may not like what they see. I’m sure that there are some who would not appreciate my rants about things I find upsetting and who also could not care less if they find out about my family life. Personally, I don’t give a hoot about this. There will be those who think my ranting is a sign of mental illness and there will be those who have no idea what I have been up to in my life – or who they would care to meet! In the end, I know that I am one of thousands and that if I were to seek help I would meet a very diverse group of people – most of them who have never even met me. I am not concerned. However, what would be the point in that – who would like to meet and deal with such a person?! So there you have it! No point in worrying – just carry on blogging the way you feel. If you feel it is important that people know about your domestic life, your children, your hobbies or your business, fine. But don’t advertise your whereabouts and try not to annoy!.

Given this story: Food There is something very elemental and satisfying about our relationship with food. I know I may be preaching to the converted because presumably people keen on cooking buy cookery books like this one but so often we imagine that unless it is some special occasion or an especially elaborate dish it is hardly worth attempting. Last week, I saw two films. The first was called The Death of Stalin. It was good in parts but could have been a lot better. The second was called A Very English Scandal. I had wanted to see this but sadly it is not shown at our local cinema. So I thought I would watch it on BBC iPlayer.      To be honest I found A Very English Scandal rather boring. While it is true that it is very revealing of political hypocrisy and the impact it has on people’s lives, I can’t imagine it is much fun to live through. Yet in watching it I found myself nodding my head in recognition and agreeing with much that was said – particularly how the cover-up affected the man and the woman it involved. That is a great achievement in itself, I suppose.      I have no interest in the Royal Family so I don’t have a preference as to the monarchy but the Queen does have an impressive stamina and ability to put one thing behind her and focus on the next. Given how many things she is currently involved in, I think many people would struggle to cope and her ability to move on is quite extraordinary.      She has, of course, had a lot of practice and I imagine being a British Head of State does not involve much new stuff. So I am surprised at the number of things the Royal Family seem to spend their time thinking about..

Among my contemporaries this was an unusual choice. Cooking was not one of the plum jobs that most of us wanted. It is on the face of it an unattractive profession. Chefs lead notoriously harsh lives: the work is long, pressured, menial - and badly paid.         But, if we break down the barriers to understanding the culture of chefs, we find that they are a very varied group. Not everyone is naturally an excellent chef and not everyone has the confidence to be one. Cooking is certainly not for everyone.               The culinary world is a very insular world. As the saying goes, cooking is the only profession where your career can be destroyed by eating another chefs food. In other words, if you like good food - and especially if you are a top cook - you are in the company of a small number of people. If you like good food and even better people then it would be worth putting yourself forward as a candidate to be a chef. But, if you do not like food or people, and especially if you are not a top chef, you may want to reconsider your future.                  We are a group of people who love eating and cooking. We also love talking about food,.

Given this story: TIM RICE I was ushered into the young man’s drawing room an oasis of cultured sanity surrounded by what appeared to be a quite shambolic cluster of rooms in which the less enterprising members of the family operated. Moving from the kitchen to his parlour was an upgrade from economy to business class. The dining room was in good repair, with several small tables and chairs and a handsome old grand piano.  In his study was a large chest of drawers, and in a corner, opposite the window, was a bookshelf stocked with various volumes – many of them volumes. He had inherited a library from an old friend and a man whom he had greatly admired – a man who had been both a close friend and an adviser in the business affairs and social life of this house. Sir Henry and Lady Manners were extremely generous with their time in an endeavour to encourage the younger generation – an undertaking in which their son played a particularly important part. In fact, they had taken great pains to ensure that their son was well educated and cultured. It was the parents’ wish that their son was a man of refinement and sophistication, and that he should become a gentleman of the first order.  Indeed, Sir Henry’s reputation for honesty, reliability and hard work as a commercial man and as a public servant was as great as if not greater than that of any other man in this house. He was, indeed, one of the most generous and popular men in the city, and his friends and admirers were many and numerous. In addition to the many prominent and wealthy merchants who kept accounts in his office, he had been a trusted adviser to one of the most important families in the city and a good friend to Sir Robert St Oswald, Lord Mayor of London..

Given this story: How to Write Poetry Telling people how to write poetry is a bit like frolicking through a minefield: spontaneity is the order of the day but one false step and a dozen certainties will blow up in your face. One of the hardest things to do with poetry is to describe the experience of writing it.  It's easy to give advice about that, but how do we know if we're giving the right advice?  If it's easy, then why does it give people such difficulty?  In fact, people tend to write poetry with an unusual lack of success in mind:  "How do I get published?"  "How do I sell my book?"  "When will my book get published?"  Those are all great questions but not the ones you're likely to encounter on your path to writing poetry.  It's more like:  "How do I write something that makes me feel good?" One way to help is to give advice that has already been expressed, by someone. Given this story: Joanna’s Lessons Joanna MacGregor has a hectic schedule as a concert pianist. So why has she added the task of writing books for young children learning the piano? Even a member of that mythical species the completely tone deaf could not fail to be stirred by a Joanna MacGregor performance. Joanna’s Lessons is a series of books aimed specifically at children who wish to learn how to play the piano and who have already been taught by a teacher. The stories are fun and engaging, written for both children who have never sat down at the piano before and children who may have been taught by their parents or other family members. In the first book, the four-year old, Tommy, has spent three years living with his Aunt and Uncle who both taught him how to write his name. However, they never showed him how to play the piano. That all changes when Uncle Phil is forced to return to the hospital and Tommy and Auntie Phylis are faced with the daunting task of looking after the house on their own. With help from his family’s neighbors, including a lovable and chatty cat, Tommy learns how to read music, how to arrange the piano keys in different keys and how to play simple melodies. But with the help of his new found friends, Tommy learns to see the piano as a magical instrument and to see his practice sessions as enjoyable family time. The result is not only a successful first book in a series but also a book with real appeal to children learning the piano, and adults who care about the wellbeing of children. Given this story: Every Picture Tells a Story Adapting novels for film almost always involves a process of reduction condensation and deletion. This can be very frustrating for the writer but also illuminating. Working on a script I was struck by how much of the dialogue and narrative description in a given scene in the novel I could dispense with while still getting across the same point. As anyone who has used Wikipedia will tell you, there is a significant issue with editing: sometimes the text changes with the addition of a new sentence. That's why, to the extent I have edited, I have usually only changed a few words. And if I really want to alter a piece of text, I'll use the spell-checker. But the editing process can reveal a great deal about the text and the author's intention. Sometimes, this is positive: as a screenwriter, I often re-work dialogue or the narration of a scene to better suit the voice of the character or script. Sometimes it's negative, as with "every picture tells a story", which is the title of the story that I am adapting. In my original novel, it was used in the middle of the second section, after a description of the setting and some background. I cut it out in my screenplay, and in doing so, revealed to myself that the author meant the entire book. Even if it did not work in the book, it was still useful in describing how the story would look on the page. That, however, did not make it a good choice to use in the final cut of the film. If I had re-used the sentence, I would have lost some of the detail in the film version. Given this story: Maps The purpose of a map is to express graphically the relations of points and features on the earth’s surface to each other. These are determined by distance and direction. A map is a graphical representation of geographic information about the Earth's surface. Map illustrations are created through the study and practice of cartography, which combines mapmaking techniques from geography with the visual arts, especially painting. The earliest known map of the world was drawn by Phoenician astronomer Ptolemy in the 2nd century BC. Mapmaking was practiced around the world before the development of printing in the 14th century. Maps are used for navigation, identification and plotting various purposes. Maps can help people to find points and points of interest (e.g., places of interest such as lakes, mountains, and volcanoes, people, and wildlife). For example, maps can identify roads or trails, the most efficient ways to travel between various points. A map can also show a route to a place. A map can help people understand a place. Some maps are illustrated to communicate information about the place, its features, and the people who live in it. Other maps are used for propaganda, and are intended to mislead, inform, or convey information. Historical maps are also commonly used as teaching tools.  To create a map, a mapmaker uses a number of different map making tools. A cartographer may use a compass to draw a meridian or a protractor to draw a line. His boldness, vision and determination helped to establish the Antarctic territory as an enduring home of scientific research. The Antarctic Treaty of 1961 put an end to war in the continent. But he will always be remembered as the man who became stranded. On 8 January 1912, Shackleton, his crew and his ship Endurance were forced to attempt the return from Antarctica of the team who had started the crossing. With Shackleton’s men having abandoned ship on their way back, with his boat stuck in a snowfield and with no hope of rescue, the captain had no choice but to abandon the ship, set out for land, and begin his return to England, using his team as a mobile tent for the journey. For the remainder of the voyage, Endurance was an iceberg. Shackleton’s story and the subsequent disaster was the subject of the book and film The Polar Bear, written by the explorer James Le Mesurier, who died in 2008. This week, the Antarctic Heritage Alliance (AHA), a UK-based organisation dedicated to the conservation of Antarctica, is celebrating what would have been the centenary of Shackleton’s second Antarctic expedition. Susan Hallam discusses their impact on music in Britain. Given this story: England’s breakfast revolution The importance of a good breakfast is beyond dispute according to health experts but in historical terms breakfast is a relatively new arrival in England with descriptions of breakfast seldom featuring in medieval literature. Bread and butter were a feature of English breakfasts until the mid-19th century, but a new study has claimed that the morning meal was almost unknown until the middle ages. By comparing medieval cookbooks, it has been found that most people were only eating simple cereals like barley or wheat or a basic meal of bread, cheese and sometimes eggs – although the French had already developed a taste for French toast centuries before then. The results point to the idea that the English first ate hearty dishes when they moved north from continental Europe at the end of the 13th century. The researchers believe the discovery highlights the role that the countryside played in the diet of people at that time. The French, who were much richer than the English at the time, took over the cuisine of the nation, largely due to the invention of the frying pan, while English cuisine underwent a “barnetisation” in which the more humble foods, such as barley or wheat, took over from expensive animal protein. However, one of the biggest changes to the typical English breakfast was the advent of the “English muffin” which was invented by Sir John Lanchester in 1713, and has now become so ingrained in the English diet it can even be argued that there is no such thing as an English breakfast without it.
